page.title: 04CHURCHES
page.content: The church of{St Mary the Virgin consists of chancel, north vestry, central tower, transepts, nave and south porch. The fabric is of 14th central origin with much refashioning in the 15th century but a drastic restoration of c. 1847 has somewhat obscured the architectural history. The most outstanding feature is the end window of the north transept with elaborate and beautiful tracery of c. (1330).The rest of the windows have been largely renewed.Painted glass in the West window and in some of the chancel windows had to be removed for safety reasons some years ago.They were replaced by clear and green tinted panes.The church was remodelled in Victorian times but fortunately the Norman font has remained intact.This is the main feature of the Lyte's Chapel which was renovated recently.
